Colin Green wrote:

>hmm, so genes that are close together tend to be functionaly dependent. 
>Genotype proximity indicates phenotype proximity. Whereas in NEAT the 
>genes always remain in the order they were added to the genome (this 
>makes comparison nice and fast), but perhaps we are loosing some 
>important properties by doing this - namely, crossover could be allowed 
>to re-arrange genes into functionaly dependent groups. Hey I like this 
>idea a lot Ian.
>  
>
I just had another idea. If I remember correctly, in nature genes are 
usually marked out with certain short sequences of DNA. Perhaps we could 
introduce the concept of a marker gene into the NEAT genome. We could 
then implement a multipoint crossover technique that is marker aware and 
hopefully genes would become re-ordered into functionaly dependent 
groups far more efficiently than using plain old random multipoint 
crossover.

Of course I am assuming that nature uses the markers during crossover as 
well as during expression of the genes. Actually it might not matter, if 
crossover ignores the markers then the genes will still form functional 
groups during expression. There may be a great deal of junk either side 
of the markers if crossover is ignoring them - but then there is all 
that 'junk' DNA isn't there.

Colin
